reasoning: The critique targets a real methodological pillar of the paper’s “systematic” argument in §3: restricting to complete vNM-style orderings (cardinalizable, continuous, independence) before arguing that “most plausible views are fussy.” If that filter were unjustified, the sociological/plausibility claim is weakened, so centrality is moderate. However, the paper also motivates “no easy eutopia” via §2-style fragility/moral-catastrophe considerations that do not rely on vNM representability, so the position wouldn’t fully collapse. The critique’s refutational force is limited because it mainly argues possible selection bias, not that the excluded families are (a) plausible on reflection and (b) in fact easygoing about futures; vNM axioms don’t by themselves force extreme sensitivity, and the paper partially acknowledges non-representable views. Still, it’s a cogent burden-shifting objection: to sustain “most plausible views,” the authors should either defend excluding incompleteness/lexical/constraint-based theories or analyze them. The critique is clear, focused, and contains little fluff.
title: Assuming vNM-complete moral orderings excludes robust theories and predetermines fussiness
